George Martin’s influence on this song is perhaps greater than at any point in The Beatles' career. His unwavering eye for a potential hit and willingness to tell his artists when their ideas were poor might not have always been what the band wanted to hear, but they grew willing to defer to his experience.

Paul McCartney said of the sessions:

He said, ‘Make it a bit faster. Let me try it.’ And he did. We thought, ‘Oh, that’s all right, yes.’ Actually, we were a bit embarrassed that he had found a better tempo than we had.
Last night, I said these words to my girl

The vocal style of this song, sung simultaneously by Lennon and McCartney, is taken wholesale from the Everly Brothers, particularly their 1960 hit Cathy’s Clown.

McCartney holds a high E harmony through the entire line, whilst Lennon descends in the primary melody. McCartney said of the Everly’s influence:

“I did the trick of remaining on the high note while the melody cascaded down from it”.

John Lennon wrote the hook as an exercise in writing using a wordplay technique called polyptoton, which he first heard on a Bing Crosby record:

I was also always intrigued by the words to a Bing Crosby song that went, ‘Please lend a little ear to my pleas.’ The double use of the word ‘please.’ So it was a combination of Roy Orbison and Bing Crosby.

Originally, “Please Please Me” was a slow, bluesy track written by John Lennon, who was influenced by Roy Orbison:

I wrote it in the bedroom in my house at Menlove Avenue, which was my auntie’s place. I remember the day and the pink coverlet on the bed and I heard Roy Orbison doing Only The Lonely or something. That’s where that came from.

When shown to producer George Martin, he didn’t take to it, calling it “dreary” and saying that it “needed pepping up.” He encouraged them to record Mitch Murray’s “How Do You Do It?” instead—a 1962 demo version of this song appeared later, on their 1995 Anthology compilation. It would also be a #1 hit for fellow Merseybeat band Gerry and the Pacemakers.

The Beatles, however, were adamant that they should focus on their own material, and Martin worked with them to turn “Please Please Me” into a more marketable single. This included the call-and-response backing vocals, showing direct influence from the doo-wop craze of the late fifties and early sixties.
